;北约立陶宛峰会在距今 500 天的背景下举行俄罗斯入侵乌克兰，导致跨大西洋联盟增加峰会频率。自冲突开始以来，该联盟已召开了三次会议，而冲突前十年召开了五次会议。

;

;尽管进行了频繁的外交讨论，但北约尚未采取细致入微的方法来解决问题解决了二战以来欧洲最重大的冲突之一。虽然会议表明成员国认识到需要找到解决方案，但持续的僵局表明需要取得更多进展。

;

;乌克兰无疑是峰会的焦点，其国防需求在议程上占据重要位置。但基辅比武器更看重的是加入北约，尽管有总统泽连斯基的压力，但加入北约的前景仍不确定。

;

;美国、匈牙利和德国等成员国对将乌克兰纳入北约存在分歧。进入联盟。与此同时，土耳其也利用瑞典加入北约作为筹码，支持自己加入欧盟的愿望。这种受国家利益驱动的行为违背了北约的安全原则，并呈现出分裂的战线。

;

;现在应该在战后欧盟与俄罗斯关系的框架内考虑乌克兰的安全问题，这一点至关重要，因为公众对乌克兰境外战争的支持越来越受到质疑。

;

;在美联社 2 月份的一项民意调查中，不到一半的美国受访者（48%）表示他们支持向乌克兰提供武器，低于 2022 年 5 月的 60%，而反对的比例为 29%。去年 12 月欧洲的民意调查显示，50% 的人支持向乌克兰提供武器，低于 3 月份的 56%，其中德国的支持率降至 48%，意大利的支持率降至 36%。

;

;下一步应该在现实政治的范式中看待。尽管与全球金融体系隔绝，俄罗斯基本上仍能维持生计，国际货币基金组织预测该国经济今年将增长 0.3%。

;

;替代供应路线和友好国家，例如印度允许该国规避美国及其盟国实施的出口管制，从而允许俄罗斯的进口和石油出口再次流动。俄罗斯经济很可能能够继续为其战争资金提供资金，并与伊朗联合开发廉价的现成解决方案，例如无人机。

;

;尽管提供了优质武器的供应，但北约必须意识到基辅无法在战争结束时解放全部领土并成功加入联盟。相反，它最大限度地发挥其存在和加入北约能力的最佳机会将来自于沿着第聂伯河被分割并随后加入该联盟。

;

;在乌克兰目前的状态下寻求加入将导致需要认真对待重新评估第五条的解释并防止针对俄罗斯的全面战争。一些盟友正在寻求通过按照以色列模式授予特别防御协议，将乌克兰转变为对抗俄罗斯的堡垒，但没有给予其完整的北约成员资格。

;

;西方应该为俄罗斯在乌克兰取得“丑陋”的胜利做好准备：政治学家

;

;以色列与美国签订了为期十年的防务协议，使其能够获得稳定的武器和弹药供应，为任何潜在的冲突做好准备。作为当前协议的一部分，以色列将从美国获得 380 亿美元，乌克兰也可以采用类似的模式。这样的法案将提供一个明确的支持机构，并防止战争如莫斯科所愿的那样被拖延。

;

;这将有助于挽救欧洲的支持并实现冲突的最终目标。然而，对于乌克兰人民来说，安全承诺历来都是徒劳的。

;

;值得注意的是，1994 年，美国在英国的保证下说服乌克兰放弃其 5,000 名苏联士兵。时代核武器。为了阻止莫斯科日益增长的敌意，所达成的协议必须足够强大，以起到可信的威慑作用。

;

;此类战略需要对乌克兰做出真诚的承诺 — — 尽管一些北约盟友可能不希望这样做 — —承认俄罗斯的安全利益，防止此类冲突再次发生。其目标不应该是武装乌克兰或强迫其加入北约，以此作为对俄罗斯的蔑视。

;

;相反，它应该建立一个可持续的安全基础设施，以承受当前和历史的地缘政治压力。这就需要改变态度，以果断取代外交僵局。如果不这样做，将会引起欧洲公众的不满，从而破坏对乌克兰的承诺。

;北约周二对中国发出迄今为止最强烈​​的谴责，猛烈抨击其“军事联盟 31 个成员国商定的联合公报对北京进行了详细的讲话，指责其不透明地增强军事实力，“放大了俄罗斯的虚假叙述”。 ”关于乌克兰战争，并利用其经济实力“建立战略依赖并增强其影响力”。

;

;在立陶宛维尔纽斯举行的领导人会议中发表，会议主要讨论乌克兰未来加入北约的机会作为成员国，该声明中有关中国的部分达到了 322 个字，而去年两份声明中的内容仅为 304 个字，而 2021 年则为 225 个字。

;

;“中国越来越多地挑战基于规则的国际秩序，拒绝谴责俄罗斯的战争北约秘书长延斯·斯托尔滕贝格 (Jens Stoltenberg) 在周二的新闻发布会上表示，这是北约为期两天的会议的第一次。

;

;“中国的核现代化是斯托尔滕贝格补充道：“这一行动的速度和规模是前所未有的，而且缺乏透明度。”

;

;北京肯定会反对这一声明和评论，就像它之前对北约的批评一样。中国对四个印太国家参与该联盟最近发生的事件表示愤怒。

;

;中国官员经常指责北约“煽风点火”乌克兰战争，并呼应了莫斯科的说法：欧盟的“东扩”是这场冲突的罪魁祸首。

;

;但这次入侵 — — 北京拒绝谴责 ​​— — 只会让北约更加大胆，在土耳其退出后，北约现在准备将瑞典纳入其第 32 个成员国峰会前夕反对其加入。

;

;分析人士称，中国和俄罗斯寻求扩大集团以替代西方秩序

;

;这也为北约与“亚洲-亚洲国家”的合作增添了动力。太平洋 4”由澳大利亚、日本、新西兰和韩国组成，每个国家都通过一系列单独协议连续第二次参加论坛，这些协议可以为更多军事互操作性和未来联合演习打开大门。

;

;AP4都是乌克兰的坚定支持者，他们都在维尔纽斯发誓要继续向基辅提供援助。

;

;“澳大利亚坚定地支持乌克兰。我们认为这是一场关于国际法治的斗争，”总理安东尼·阿尔巴内斯在周二会见斯托尔滕贝格之前说道。

;

;但是，在亚太地区首次实体存在的计划仍在继续日本曾希望在东京设立北约联络处，其外交部长林吉正 (Yoshimasa Hayashi) 则表示，六月表示这是必要的，因为自俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来，世界“变得更加不稳定”。

;

;但法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙上周否决了该计划，他的助手告诉记者，“北约代表着周二，当谈判代表敲定联合声明的最终文本时，所有提及联络处的内容都被删除了。早些时候的草案曾承诺继续讨论北约在日本的存在，这一建议引起了北京的强烈回应。

;

;“我们想说，亚太地区不欢迎集体对抗，外交部发言人毛宁此前表示：“俄罗斯不欢迎军事对抗。”

;

;俄罗斯在中国以外设立第一个习近平意识形态研究中心

;

;参加会谈的外交官在会上发言一位不愿透露姓名的人士表示，该办公室的牺牲是为了让北约能够与日本和韩国达成伙伴关系协议。这些交易被认为比东京的一个人联络处更具实质性。

;

;“法国希望将其从公报中删除，以便就其他地方的伙伴关系达成一致，”一位外交官表示，并补充说巴黎将”未能采取建设性行动结束乌克兰战争。

;

;“中国和俄罗斯之间不断深化的战略伙伴关系及其相互强化的破坏基于规则的国际秩序的企图与我们的价值观和利益背道而驰，”

;

;中国和俄罗斯举行导弹防御会谈：莫斯科

;

;它呼吁中国“作为联合国安理会常任理事国发挥建设性作用”，谴责声明还谴责北京涉嫌传播与战争有关的虚假信息，要求中国“停止放大俄罗斯指责乌克兰和乌克兰的错误言论”。北约支持俄罗斯对乌克兰的侵略战争，并遵守《联合国宪章》的宗旨和原则”。

;

;这种语言，加上 AP4 的存在，肯定会激怒中国政府，欧洲外交关系委员会的阿利恰·巴楚斯卡 (Alicja Bachulska) 表示：“北京越来越将北约视为美国遏制俄罗斯和中国的工具。” “对中国来说，AP4代表参加维尔纽斯峰会意味着美国有更多的资源和政治意愿来关注印太地区。”

;

;AP4将于周三与所有北约成员国会面。他们还可能会见乌克兰总统泽连斯基，后者于周二晚上抵达维尔纽斯，阐述基辅加入北约的理由。

;

;

;

;

;美联社通常不会透露性侵犯指控的受害者身份，但本报告中提到了钟和其他人的名字选择公开表明自己的身份。

;

;“他非常严肃地批评性骚扰，充满正义感，对吧在我面前，”钟在脸书上发帖写道。 “他怎么敢？”她说，她决定发声，以纪念最初迫使她从政的价值观。

;

;朱后来在 Facebook 上公开道歉，称他正在配合检察官。 “我愿意承担一切后果和法律责任。”

;Canada will ease its pathway to permanent residency for Hongkongers by removing all educational requirements for those who have worked in the country for a year following an outcry by some applicants that the previous youth-focused policy was unfair to immigrants who had long since left university.

;

;Ottawa on Tuesday said Hongkongers could apply for permanent residency after working in the country for at least a year and no longer needed postsecondary education to be eligible. Experience under Canada's working holiday scheme will also count.

;

;Canada grants 21,000 work visas to Hongkongers but residency rules trip some

;

;Previously only residents who had obtained degrees in the past five years were eligible to apply.

;

;The new arrangement comes into effect on August 15.

;

;“Removing this requirement means more Hongkongers who have worked in Canada will be eligible for permanent residency, easing the transition to permanent status for those who are already working in Canada under the open work permit programme,” Paul Chiang, parliamentary secretary to the minister of housing and diversity and inclusion, said on behalf of the immigration minister.

;

;But Chiang said Hongkongers still needed to have graduated in the past 10 years to apply for an open work permit, which allows the holder to move to Canada without needing to secure a job first.

;

;Chiang said those employed in Canada under the “working holiday programme” were also eligible to apply for permanent residence after a year.

;

;The relaxation was prompted in part by an outcry from some older applicants, especially those who graduated in 2016 and 2017, who would be ineligible to apply after working the required one year.

;

;'Fast track to PR' helps Canada become top choice of Hong Kong students

;

;They formed a concern group, numbering in the hundreds, to lobby the Canadian government and lawmakers for a change.

;

;Concern group representative Connie Chan, 29, a 2016 university graduate, said they were thrilled to hear about the expansion which made them eligible for permanent residency.

;

;“Our demand was just to expand the scheme to cover 2016 and 2017 graduates, but it turned out the result is better than expected,” she said.

;

;Canada, Britain and Australia created special immigration pathways for Hongkongers following Beijing's imposition of the national security law in 2020.

;

;But Canada has the lowest barrier to entry and targets younger people, recent graduates and those who have studied in the country.

;

;Thousands quit Hong Kong, saying it's no longer the home they knew

;

;The pathway is also open to those who have chalked up at least 1,560 hours of employment under a three-year open work permit. The graduates are allowed to apply for the permits without getting a job first, and once it is granted, their spouses and dependants can also move to Canada.

;

;In February, the country announced that Hongkongers who had graduated in the past five years could apply for the three-year open work permit.

;

;Britain, Canada, US and Taiwan popular options for Hongkongers leaving city

;

;As of April, the government had granted 3,169 Hongkongers permanent residency out of 5,541 applications through the study and work schemes. A total of 78 applications were refused and 23 withdrew their applications. The country issued 22,596 open work permits to arrivals from the city.

;

;Of the approved, 68 per cent were granted to those aged 25 to 54, while 31 per cent went to those aged 18 to 24.

;As a child, a dark tunnel at the entrance of our village in Nanjing frightened us children. Rumours even suggested it was haunted. The tunnel was actually an air defence shelter. Constructed in the late 1960s and early 1970s, they were all over Chinese cities in case the United States or the Soviet Union, the two largest powers in the world, attacked us.

;

;The Cold War has long since been buried in the dust of history, but it is not unthinkable that we could be heading into a new cold war and that children from both sides will have to live in a climate of fear once again. The tensions between China and the US are rising, and public opinion in both countries is not helping.

;

;In early June, a survey of more than 2,000 Chinese people conducted by Stanford University found that 75 per cent of respondents held negative views of the US. The same survey showed that American respondents' views of China were similarly negative at 76 per cent. The findings are in line with other polls that show unfavourable views of each other are at record lows.

;

;Another poll by the Roper Centre in the US found that Americans' views of China have started to resemble their views of the Soviet Union decades ago in terms of hostility, pessimism and militarism.

;

;This mutual negative feeling towards each other is worrying as it could fuel tensions between the two, which are already high.

;

;The relationship between China and the US has experienced a roller-coaster ride. After Richard Nixon's visit to China in the early 1970s, which broke the political ice, a brief honeymoon period emerged. In Chinese, the US is meiguo, or “beautiful country”. Millions of Chinese people, myself included, took this to heart. The US was seen as a dream country with its freedom, democratic system and opportunity for all.

;

;In recent decades, this view soured. The bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade in 1999 and the Hainan incident two years later when a US intelligence plane and a Chinese jet collided helped erode ties. Former US president Donald Trump's trade war further alienated China. Finally, Russian President Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine and China's failure to condemn the invasion have further poisoned the relationship.

;

;In the US, Republicans and Democrats seem to compete over who can be tougher on China. This trend reinforces the negative image of China among the general public. This low point of public opinion could in turn drive the political leaders to take even more hawkish positions on China.

;

;The record low opinion of the US in China is attributed to many factors. Naturally, public opinion is influenced by its media and leaders' hardened attitudes towards the US. Back in March during the all-important National People's Congress, President Xi Jinping – a more assertive leader compared to his predecessors – bluntly blamed the US and its “comprehensive containment” of China for the country's slow economic recovery.

;

;Some Chinese intellectuals and opinion leaders also feel disillusioned about the US because of its many problems, such as its polarised and unequal society, political corruption, gun crime, debt issues and so on.

;

;Yellen, Blinken meetings won't fix what ails US-China relations

;

;Does public opinion matter in an authoritarian country such as China, where there is no democratic voting system? The answer is yes, even though the correlation between public opinion and government decision-making is perhaps less strong compared to that of the US. There have been suggestions that Xi sharpened his rhetoric because he didn't want to be seen as weak by the people of China.

;

;The Chinese government does respond to public opinion as it cares about its political legitimacy, as shown in its sudden abandonment of its zero-Covid policy. The increasingly negative public views of the US could encourage its leaders to take a harder line against the US. This vicious circle is dangerous as the dramatic deterioration of the relationship will not be good for either country.

;

;Disturbing as it is to see views of China in the US resembling those of the Soviet Union during the Cold War, I am not surprised as American politicians often lump Russia and China together. The difference between China and the Soviet Union is as wide as that between heaven and earth, though.

;

;China is much more economically powerful, and its economy is deeply entwined with that of the US. That wasn't the case with the Soviet Union. This incorrect impression is likely to lead to miscalculations in foreign policy decision-making.

;

;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to China was intended to mend ties. However, soon after US President Joe Biden called Xi a “dictator”. Such comments only darken China's image and worsen the relationship. Both sides should avoid such rhetoric. Great powers should tolerate a great deal of ambiguity in their relationships if they ultimately believe peace serves their interests.

;

;Many air defence shelters in China have been dismantled and converted into underground shopping centres or tourist venues. Let them stay that way.

;

;A Russian military officer who had commanded a submarine in the Black Sea and appeared on a Ukrainian blacklist of alleged war criminals has been shot dead by an unknown assassin while on his morning run.

;

;Stanislav Rzhitsky, 42, was gunned down early on Monday in the southern Russian city of Krasnodar. His address, picture and personal details had appeared on the Ukrainian website Myrotvorets (Peacemaker), a vast unofficial database of people considered to be enemies of Ukraine.

;

;On Tuesday the word “Liquidated”, in red letters, had been superimposed on his photograph on the site.

;

;Russia's state Investigative Committee said on Tuesday it had arrested a suspect in his early 60s who was found in possession of a pistol and silencer. It published a short video showing heavily armed security officers storming a house and detaining the man, who was wearing only boxer shorts.

;

;Ukraine's GUR military intelligence agency published details of the killing on its website, without claiming responsibility or saying how it obtained the information.

;

;It said Rzhitsky died on the spot when seven shots were fired at him from a Makarov pistol as he was running in a deserted city park at around 6am.

;

;Baza, a Russian Telegram channel with links to the security services, said the killer could have tracked Rzhitsky's movements on an app where he posted details of his regular jogging route in Krasnodar and how long he took to complete it.

;

;Russian state media and war bloggers said Rzhitsky was deputy head of military mobilisation in the city and had previously commanded the “Krasnodar” submarine in the Black Sea.

;

;Wagner will keep part of its African empire after Russian mutiny

;

;A Telegram channel used by self-styled pro-Ukraine partisans who have claimed hundreds of sabotage attacks inside Russia said – without stating evidence – that Rzhitsky was suspected of involvement in a submarine-launched cruise missile strike in July 2022 that killed at least 23 people including a 4-year-old girl in the Ukrainian city of Vinnytsia.

;

;Baza quoted Rzhitsky's father as saying he had resigned from the military at the end of 2021 and been discharged, after a delay, the following August.

;

;At least two other pro-war Russian figures in the Myrotvorets database have been assassinated inside Russia since Russian forces invaded Ukraine nearly 17 months ago. Bomb attacks killed journalist Darya Dugina last August and war blogger Vladlen Tatarsky in April.

;

;Russia has blamed Ukraine for the attacks. Kyiv has denied involvement, suggesting the attacks are the result of Russian infighting.
